title: How to find the first and second derivative of f(x) in terms of g’ and g’’ if f(x) =g(x^3) + e^g(3x) - Quora

response.answer_text: You just apply the chain rule for derivatives: [math]\frac{d}{dx}(f(g(x))=(f(g(x))'=f'(g(x))g'(x)[/math] In English: multiply the derivative of the outer function by the derivative of the inner function. I don't want to give you the exact answer in case this is a homework problem, so let’s look at a similar problem: [math]f(x)=g(x^2)+sin(g(3x))[/math] To find the first derivative, applying the chain rule to to first term gives [math]2xg'(x^2)[/math]. For the second term, it might look more complicated, but it's the same idea — we just have to apply the chain rule twice. Applying it the first time, we get [math]cos(g(3x)(g(3x)'[/math]. Now apply it again to evaluate [math](g(3x)'[/math]. That gives [math]3g'(3x)[/math]. So putting it all together, we get [math]f'(x)=2xg'(x^2)+3g'(3x)cos(g(3x))[/math]. Now the second derivative. That's a little trickier because now we need the product rule as well as the chain rule: [math](fg)'=f'g+g'f[/math]. Ok, first term: apply the product rule, which includes applying the chain rule to the [math]g'(x^2)[/math] in the second half of the product rule — [math]2g'(x^2)+2xg''(x^2)*2x[/math] Now the second term: same process as we just did except remember to multiply everything by [math]3[/math] and we need to apply the chain rule twice in the second half of the product rule— [math]3[3g''(3x)cos(g(3x))-3g'(3x)sin(g(3x))*g'(3x)][/math] Now, putting it all together, [math]f''(x)=2g'(x^2)+2xg''(x^2)*2x+3[3g''(3x)cos(g(3x))-3g'(3x)sin(g(3x))*g'(3x)]=[/math] [math]f''(x)=2g'(x^2)+4x^2g''(x^2)+9[g''(3x)cos(g(3x))-(g'(3x))^2sin(g(3x))][/math]. Hopefully that helps. Let me know if you'd like any clarification. ;)
First use the Chain Rule.  Then apply the Product Rule and the Chain Rule.
